title: MRFF Site v1 intro

Page Description: Our journey to saving Dhanvi’s leg using phage therapy
Name: 1. Main narrative: Dhanvi: Saving a girl’s legs from amputation

Notes: Dhanvi: Saving a girl’s legs from amputation

:
Dhanvi is picture of phages working; Mallory is example of someone needing phages, but too slow;
to save more Dhanvis and prevent Mallorys from dying

: Example of phages saving a person; shows it’s safe, effective, helps people already, and can save more people; use Dhanvi’s ex to illustrate process of getting phages as a patient, and a bit about what goes on behind the scenes;
Join Phage Australia; Find a Doc
How we used viruses to save a girl’s legs e.g.
Name: 1. Main narrative: Dhanvi: Saving a girl’s legs from amputation

Page Description: 7-year-old Dhanvi was in a car accident
a
https://www.abc.net.au/7.30/our-growing-resistance-to-antibiotics-may-be-an/13059088
. Her leg was about to be amputated due to an infection that antibiotics failed to cure.
Page Title: How we use viruses to save lives and limbs
Name: 2. Secondary narrative: How viruses saved a girl’s legs

Notes: How viruses saved a girl’s legs

:
Phages and the science behind Dhanvi’s treatment worked; her treatment embodies that it works; “what is phage therapy” and “how does it work”
Show how complicated the parts are — and what we’re doing to make phages cheaper, and much faster accessible for future Dhanvis — through workflow, lab, computing, biobanking, etc. (but dial back on jargon)
We put a huge science team together to treat thousands of Dhanvis
We are running a massive clinical trial called STAMP

: use Dhanvi’s ex to illustrate process of getting phages as a patient, a lot more about what goes on behind the scenes; dip into the science, explain how phages work to kill bacteria; emphasize safety (Dhanvi is happy and healthy today)
Join Phage Australia; Find a Doc
: How does the STAMP clinical trial work?
Name: 2. Secondary narrative: How viruses saved a girl’s legs

Page Description: We’re on a mission to save lives with phage therapy
Cover Caption: Phage Australia’s clinical sites. Image credit: Stephanie Lynch
Name: 3. About PhAus Org

Notes: The right people for the right job
About our experiences, who we are, and collectively what have we done before. Includes publications, profile pages, funding etc.
Name: 3. About PhAus Org

Page Description: Phage Australia takes a personalized, data-driven approach to phage therapy
Name: 4. Our Approach

Notes: As much as required; sub pages ok. Might use documentation-style pages, e.g.

Focus: STAMP clinical trial; science heavy documentation
This section is less about explaining “what is phage therapy” and more about how STAMP and Australia-led phage therapy works. Emphasize informatics and data collection, patient monitoring, massive distributed phage bank and speeding up process of getting phages to patients.
Talk about expenses, workflows + SOPs, how much it should take per patient, QA/QC for phages, manufacturing steps, etc. Add graphs from the grant.
Connect back to Dhanvi.
Talk about the clinical trial, TGA, and outcome-based treatments.
Become a part of the network
Name: 4. Science: Australian-made phage therapy / stamp

NSW Health & Medical Research | A therapy from the past could hold the key to beating antibiotic resistance in the future

title: Phage Australia takes a personalised, data-driven approach to phage therapy
To make phage therapy available to all Australians who need it, it needs to be approved as a medicine. To do this, we need to
achieve
i
and
demonstrate
i
good outcomes.
Phage therapy has long been available for
everyone
i
and
no one
i
at the same time. We’re changing this.
Phage therapy has been done
thousands of times
a
https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/abs/pii/S1473309921006125
, but we still don’t have
proof
i
that
i
it works. Why? Because clinical trials aren’t set up for personalised therapeutics. Unlike other drugs, using the same phages on everyone doesn’t work.
Until now, we’ve had two options:
Use the same phages on everyone, compare outcomes (traditional clinical trial)
Use the phages each patient needs, don’t compare outcomes (compassionate use)
What if we didn’t have to choose? What if we treated and monitored everyone the same way, but each person got their own phages?
STAMP: a unique phage therapy trial
STAMP stands for Standardised Treatment and Monitoring Protocol for Adults and Pediatric Patients.

The STAMP protocol is unlike other commercial or investigator-initiated clinical trials where a specific therapy has been produced/manufactured by the 'sponsor' of the trial. In STAMP, it is not the phages themselves being studied. Rather, STAMP is evaluating the clinical
protocol
i
for administering and monitoring phage therapy. In other words, STAMP looks at the
process,
i
not the
product
i
. STAMP allows us to treat more patients with personalised phages, without sacrificing the standardised dosing and outcome monitoring that comes with clinical trials.
Why is it important to study process over product?
In STAMP, the phages used (and the site of infection) are always different. STAMP allows phages to always be tailored to the patient’s specific bacteria.
How are the phages themselves regulated?
In STAMP, the phage therapy itself will be provided via the Therapeutic Goods Administration’s Special Access Scheme.
STAMP endorsed by all clinicians and researchers within the Phage Australia network
STAMP
endorsed by ASID
a
https://www.asid.net.au/groups/endorsed-studies
, Australia’s national infectious disease physician society, as well as its pediatric arm
STAMP
doses first patient
a
https://twitter.com/PhageAustralia/status/1527545731879292928
, an 8-year-old girl in Sydney, with phage in April 2022
How our phage therapy process works

We prioritise speed (minimising patient wait times) and data collection (we document everything so we can use what we learn). This involves steps across four phases: before patient enrolment, upon patient enrolment, during treatment, and after treatment.
We are dozens of labs and hospitals across Australia  →
We’ve identified steps we can do
before
i
we have a patient in need, to minimise phage wait times.
We find phages and add them to our biobank
We pre-certify our phages for safety
We make and store patient-ready phages
Our network finds and classifies phages in advance, adding to our growing
phage biobank
a
https://phageaustralia.org/biobank
We sequence each phage’s DNA and certify each for safety.
We produce pure phage batches and get them certified for quality, so they’re ready when patients need them.
When a patient is deemed eligible for phage therapy, their doctor can order a phage that targets their patient’s specific bacteria.
We pick out the right phage
We test it with the patient’s antibiotics
The patient’s doctor sends us a culture of the target bacteria. We test our phages until we find one that’s active against it.
We test phages in combination with antibiotics the patient may take, so we know they work well together.
Our biobank ships the phage to the patient’s hospital pharmacy.
Once the phage is produced and shipped, we support pharmacists, nurses and doctors through STAMP, our standardised dosing and monitoring protocol.
We provide protocols and support so that:
We provide protocols, data collection systems and lab support so that:
Pharmacists prepare phages the same way each time
As much relevant patient data is collected as possible
Nurses and doctors give phages at the same concentration, duration, and frequency for each patient
Patient samples are collected in the same way at the same times
Samples are processed the same way each time
We analyse data from each case
We analyse data across all cases
What metrics give us the most valuable information?
What are markers of a ‘good’ phage?
What are markers of a patient who will benefit?
Show it’s feasible, show it works
The key to phage access is achieving and demonstrating outcomes
To make phage therapy available to all Australians who need it, we need to:
Be prepared and ready for patients
Standardise dosing and monitoring for all patients
Get phage therapy approved as a medicine
With your help, we can amass the data we need to get phage therapy approved as a medicine in Australia.
Add your lab or hospital to the Phage Australia network →
